body:
Did the empty files have temporary prefixes?
Do you have a custom number of copier routines?

As for the second issue, I guess this is expected, or do you suggest to delete files which you ignored?
How do we know if the ignored file has any value or not.

During the transfer process they have the prefix .syncthing. Once I remove the files on the source end the prefixes are removed but the empty files with the same name that was on the source end remains. 

This happened to me last week but I did not realize how until I ran this test. I copied a lot of pictures from my camera to my desktop. They were syncing while I went through the pictures. I deleted the ones that I did not want to keep on my desktop. Later I noticed a lot of empty files on my laptop. Because all of the file names look the same I was not sure if they were the ones I had deleted on the desktop. Now it seems clear that they were ready to sync when I deleted them and the empty file was left behind.

The error on the web interface is:
10:11:29: Folder "ST" isn't making progress - check logs for possible root cause. Pausing puller for 1m0s.

The console error is:
[xxxxx] 10:12:30 INFO: Puller (folder "ST", dir "MB"): delete: remove /Test/ST/MB: directory not empty

I'm not sure what you mean by "Do you have a custom number of copier routines?".

The second issue is a lot trickier. I had not submitted a an issue report because I'm not sure how to handle it. Automatically deleting ignored files on either end is not a good idea since whey may have started there and you just don't want to sync them. I guess ideally the interface would provide more useful information, not just "isn't making progress". The logs, which don't exist unless you pipe the output somewhere, aren't very specific. It actually points to the base directory, not even the one that has the empty (or ignored) files in it. It would help if the logs named the files that are blocking the directory removal and mentioned that the files that are left behind are in the .stignore list. Ideally the web interface would tell you exactly what is left behind, mentioned that the only files left behind are in the .stignore list and asked you if they should be deleted.

Consider this case:

I have directory DirA with files File1.txt File2.txt. I sync it between 2 computers. Then I decide I don't want to sync File2.txt so I add it to .stignore.

A week later I decide to rename DirA to DirB. On the other computer I get a new directory named DirB with File1.txt in it and I still have DirA with File2.txt in it.

On the receiving end the web interface tells me it's not making progress, check the logs. The console output tells me it can't delete DirA because it's not empty.

Automatically deleting directory DirA could lead to problems, syncing File2.txt to the new location violates the .stignore settings so neither makes sense. If there was a way to recognize the special case where syncthing is trying to delete a directory that is not empty and the only files left in the directories are also in the .stignore file and give an option to delete them from the web interface that might work.

This happened to me several times because I noticed lots of files syncing that were never going to be needed on the other end. I think I have 6 file names that are no longer synced but were originally synced to many of the directories on the other computer. (i.e. desktop.ini). Any time I rename, relocate, remove a directory with any of these files in it syncthing has a problem. A quick find command cleans up the mess but it would be nice if it was easier.

I don't think 2nd issue will ever be fixed as there is no good way of fixing it.
Offering to delete some random files which we are not even supposed to see doesn't make a lot of sense.
Plus, if you choose not to delete the files the problem persists still requiring manual intervention.
You do bring the problem upon yourself to be honest, as it's your choice to ignore these files, hence it's your responsibility to manage them because they are not managed by syncthing.

We do plan to eventually scrap ignores in favour of selective sync, where you select which directories to sync oppose to which file extensions, so I guess this sort of could solve the issue as you might not even be able to ignore anything.

Back to the first issue, syncthing does not 'pre-create' files, it only creates them at the point it starts writing to them. Can you reliably reproduce the bug? If yes, what are the exact steps?

Like I said, my second issue was, well secondary. I only mentioned it because it has something in common with my main issue. I will setup a test and try it on both syncthing and btsync and see if it behaves any differently.

When you scrap .stingore will there still be a way to block syncing based on file name? This is a must have feature for me since there are many temporary files that I never want to sync.

I have reproduced the problem several times. it happened with the pictures last weekend and I recreated after your first reply.

Oddly enough I just tried again with a new file tree and it did not happen. What actually happens is only one .syncthing.FILENAME is created while it's being synced. Right after I move the files out of the source directory all of the remaining .syncthing.FILENAME are created with zero size and then they are gone.

The only difference between this and the earlier tests was the number of directories. In the earlier test the files were 2 directories deep, in the test that worked they were 1 directory deep.

So I added another directory. It did the same thing at first, only one .syncthing.FILENAME file at a time, then it created the missing .syncthing.FILENAME files after they were deleted on the source but this time they stayed zero size and were renamed FILENAME.

I have copied the ls outputs below.

I am running tests many different ways and I'm seeing different results. Sometimes I have zero size files left and sometimes I don't. In one of my tests I've added a second copy of the files in a second directory 2 deep.

In one case I have ST/Dir1/BMC with 10 50MB files.

In the other case I have ST/Dir2/BMC1 and ST/Dir2/BMC2 each with 10 50 MB files.

Directory ST in the shared directory.

I have not looked at the code and have never worked with Go so these are user observations.

When the files are being synced one .syncthing.FILENAME exists. soon after the source files disappear the reaming .syncthing.FILENAME are created as if a loop was just waiting for the first one to complete and instead of existing it quickly made the remaining .syncthing.FILENAME files. 

In the case when there are two directories two deep in the file system the files get renamed FILENAME and they are left behind.

In the case when there are two directories two deep in the file system the first temporary file to be synced in the second directory (.syncthing.FILENAME) is created along with the remaining .syncthing.FILENAME files int he first directory and then they are all deleted properly.

I will keep testing to make sure this is consistent. I hope this makes a little sense and helps. If not let me know and I will try to clarify.

# 

ls command run from the base of the Shared directory.

===== While syncing=====
root@CloudBMC3:/Cloud1/BMC/Test/ST# ll Dir/BMC/
total 72968
drwxr-xr-x 2 cloud Cloud     4096 Jan 17 15:49 ./

`So I added another directory. It did the same thing at first, only one .syncthing.FILENAME file at a time, then it created the missing .syncthing.FILENAME files after they were deleted on the source but this time they stayed zero size and were renamed FILENAME.`
I don't understand this part.
Why are you creating files which you are not supposed to?

```
When the files are being synced one .syncthing.FILENAME exists. soon after the source files disappear the reaming .syncthing.FILENAME are created as if a loop was just waiting for the first one to complete and instead of existing it quickly made the remaining .syncthing.FILENAME files.
```

This sentence is very unclear `renaming FILENAME are created`?
`Existing it quickly?`

Sorry, does this help?

When the files are being synced one .syncthing.FILENAME exists. Soon after the source files disappear the remaining .syncthing.FILENAME files are created as if a loop was just waiting for the first one to complete and instead of exiting the loop it quickly made the remaining .syncthing.FILENAME files.

Simply put, if 10 files are being synced and 3 are done, one is in progress and 6 are waiting, the 3 that are done have the source file name, the one being synced has the .syncthing prefix and there is no sign of the other 6 on the destination computer.

As soon as the source files are moved out of the path in the sync folder the 6 files that were in the queue appear as empty files on the destination computer with the .syncthing prefix and zero size. I think they are then renamed to without the prefix and then sometimes they vanish and sometimes the zero files are left behind.

This all happens pretty quickly so I may moss some of the changes.

Here are the ls results from before the source files are moved, right after they are moved and then 5 or 10 seconds later. This is for 2 directories 2 deep (Dir2/BMC1 & DIR2/BMC2). I created 10 MB brick files in BMC1 and 20 MB brick files in BMC2 so it's easier to see which are which in the ls output.

I am continuing to run this test and sometimes it works as expected and sometimes it leave zero size files behind. So far changing the paths or having 2 sub folders does not guarantee results either way. My best guess is that it depends on when during the sync process the source files disappear. I have noticed that the next .syncthing.FILEBANE file appears right before the one being synced finished syncing (the file is slightly less than the final size) so maybe that timing or some other timing is part of the problem. You can see this happen in the ls output below. .syncthing.BRICK-010MB-002 is not quite done but .syncthing.BRICK-010MB-003 has been created.

During sync

```
cloud@CloudBMC3:/Cloud1/BMC/Test/ST$ ls -lha */*

drwxr-xr-x 4 cloud Cloud 4.0K Jan 17 16:57 ..

```

yeah something is not right.
Which version are you running?

I just reran the most recent test that I posted and this time it worked perfectly. This time I waited until the third file was syncing before the source files vanished.
I just tried again removing the source files when the second file was syncing and it worked fine. Twice in a row.
I suggest you set STTRACE environment variable to `model` and gather some logs.

I think I may have stumbled onto to the reason it seems inconsistent. I can control when the problem happens and when it does not happen (or at least I think I can).

The first time I sync the files the problem happens. On subsequent syncs it does not.

I have a script that I use to dump /dev/urandom into the brick files so that the content of each file is unique.

When I made new files alongside the existing files the only ones left behind are the new ones that did not start or finish syncing and had never been synced (or attempted any way since most did not ever sync).

This appears to be file name based not file content based.

When I rename one of the files that has been synced before it is left behind after the source files are removed.

When I change the content of an existing file but do not change the name the file is not left behind.

When I rename the source directory (but not the files) the problem happens on the first sync but not on subsequent syncs. This appears to mean that it's not just file name based but full path and file name based.

The "file name memory" appears to survive when I restart syncthing.
Can this be reproduced with v0.11?

Yes it can but not every time. I have run about 50 tests tonight trying to reproduce the error and I get it sometimes and other times it works correctly. I think I'm close to being able to describe a reproducible failure and will let you know when I figure out the recipe.
:+1: That'd be great.

I have run dozens of tests at this point and the only thing I can tell you is that sometimes Syncthing works as expected and sometimes it leaves empty files behind. I have tried to figure out what is different between the tests and it's hard to see a pattern.

I have generated hundreds of files with random data in them to try to figure out when the files are left behind and then they are not. I have put them in many different file structures to see if that matters. All of my test files work some times and fail at other times. I can try the samedirectories and files3 times in a row and some times works all 3 times and sometimes it fails 1, 2 or all 3 times.

I have set the rescan interval on both ends to 6000 seconds so that I can control the rescans. It does not seem to matter which system (sending or receiving) rescans first. It can work or fail either way. Ihavealso tried moving the files out of the Syncthing test folder early in the sync process (during the first file sync) and later int he process and it makes no difference.

I have tried to see if rescanning the source server before I get the puller pausing error on the receiving server matters but it's hard to be sure since I can't control when the error takes place.

The only test thatalwaysfails is when I move a bunch of MP3 files into the testdirectoryand then move it out before the sync is done. Every time I do that some empty files are left behind alongwith the directory structure. The MP3 directory hasabout1200 files and folders in it.

There appears to be some variable in my actions that I can not track down. This is the definition of insanitybecausethe best I can tell I'm doing the samethingover and over and gettingdifferentresults and it is making me insane.

As I recall when I first ran into this problem several months Syncthing left behind zero size files on the receiving server for every file that was queued up to sync but had not finished syncing. Now what I am finding is that not all files that have not synced are being left behind as empty files. When my test fails on the same batch of files more than once it leaves a different set of empty files behind. When the batch of files includes copies of the same files in different folders (to see if the number of files matters) syncthing was able to sync the secondary copies of any file that had completed syncing one copy even after the source files were no longer available. This syncing without the source continues until the source server rescans. Pretty cool bandwidth saving feature but could that code be involved in this bug? My conclusion in January was that the empty files were only left behind the first time a batch of files was synced and disappeared before they were done. Subsequent syncs where the files disappeared were handled properly. It's not that easy to reproduce now so something appears to have changed to partially fix the old cause.

It's been a while since I first reported this bug and it seems like it's better than it was. I think I've seen it return the empty files from the receiving server to the sending server in the past and I have not seen that happen with 0.11.05.

Good luck figuring this out and let me know if you want me to run an additional tests.

I just ran one more test. I created 9 100 MB files in my Syncthing test folder and then had it rescan. The scan began. I delete the files on the sending server while the first file was syncing. The files all had new random data in them but some or all of the file names probably match files that had been synced in the past 24 hours.

It looks like it's about the same as January.
Can you run these tests with STTRACE=model, it's going to be very verbose, but make sure you only capture the logs on the occasion when it fails.
On the sending end, the receiving end or both?

On the receiving one, which as far as I understand the end which has the files left behind.
Also, take note of some files which are left empty.
Where can I send it? Even though this is a test config for Syncthing i don't feel comfortable posting the log publicly.
Just rip out the personal stuff such as IP's and device ids

Can't upload the logs and there are too many characters to post so he is a link to the log file.

coupeware.com/Download/model.syncthing.log.gz

i have the same problem: created a directory (with many subdirectories with sub... and many files in it) and few minutes later deleted it. now i have on the other nodes directories with zero length files which can not be deleted.  (all systems have 0.11.5 on debian linux jessie)
(and the message "folder cannot make progress"... it would be  helpful if at least some of the error messages would be given here. it is hard to find them, because there is no (not yet) a systematic log - i guess the log should be added in the init.d or systemd file)

@CoupeWare can you try this build: http://build.syncthing.net/job/syncthing-pr/589/
It has more logging, so please provide the log again.
